nodes.text: MINPSID can mitigate loss of silent data corruption (SDC) coverage of selective instruction duplication (SID) when protected HPC programs run with multiple different inputs by identifying and re-prioritizing incubative instructions
Existing selective instruction duplication (SID) methods evaluate protection using a single reference input and assume program error resiliency is similar across inputs

We use a fault model that injects single-bit flips into LLVM IR instruction return values to represent transient hardware faults in processor computing components, ignoring memory ECC and control logic faults
Fault injection experiments across 11 HPC benchmarks with 30-50 random inputs show that SID's expected SDC coverage often decreases substantially when evaluated on different inputs

A small set of instructions, called incubative instructions, exhibit near-zero SDC probability under the reference input but much higher SDC probability under other inputs and are responsible for most SDC coverage loss

Measured SDC coverage decreased from average 96.12% to 58.76% over 11 benchmarks when running existing SID with multiple inputs; on average 37.58% of inputs per benchmark cause coverage loss and some benchmarks show up to 100% loss

MINPSID is an automated framework that (a) identifies incubative instructions using static analysis plus a genetic algorithm input search guided by weighted control-flow graphs, (b) measures per-instruction SDC probabilities via fault injection on selected inputs, and (c) re-prioritizes incubative instructions in SID instruction selection

SID formulates instruction selection as a 0-1 knapsack: per-instruction cost equals dynamic cycles fraction and benefit equals SDC probability times cost, so low measured benefit under the reference input leads to nonselection

MINPSID's input search engine uses a genetic algorithm with mutation and crossover to generate inputs and evaluates fitness by average Euclidean distance between indexed weighted CFG lists derived from dynamic basic block execution counts

After discovering incubative instructions, MINPSID updates their benefits to the maximum observed across tested inputs so the knapsack selection will prioritize them and then applies LLVM-based code transformation to duplicate selected instructions

Per-instruction fault injection is expensive if performed on many random inputs, so MINPSID reduces cost by guiding input selection to expose diverse execution paths and incubative instructions with fewer inputs
MINPSID identifies more incubative instructions faster than a random searcher, finding on average 45.60% more incubative instructions within similar time budgets and converging with fewer inputs
Evaluation on 11 benchmarks shows MINPSID mitigates on average 97% of SID's loss of SDC coverage across inputs and reduces the average percentage of inputs causing coverage loss from 37.58% to 8.36%

MINPSID incurs an average one-time analysis cost of 63.71 minutes per benchmark (dominated by per-instruction FIs and input search); per-instruction FI for incubative identification averaged 26.42 minutes

Limitations include one-time compilation cost and remaining variance in actual duplicated dynamic instruction fraction across inputs (MINPSID shows similar overhead variance as SID), and possible benchmark- and LLVM-level FI specificities
